content:
Yes, tensions between Japan and Russia had been mounting in the region for several years prior to the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-1905. Both Japan and Russia had been competing for influence in Korea and other parts of East Asia, and there had been a number of diplomatic and military incidents that had raised tensions between the two countries.

For example, in 1903, Russia had refused to recognize Japan's annexation of Korea as legitimate, which led to a breakdown in diplomatic relations between the two countries. Japan also saw Russian naval expansion in the region as a direct threat to its own strategic and economic interests, particularly given Russia's lease of Port Arthur from China.

As tensions continued to mount, both Japan and Russia began to build up their military forces in the region, including their naval fleets. This eventually led to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, which saw significant naval and land battles fought between the two countries in Korea and other parts of East Asia.
